message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms of constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash suggest post-herpetic neuralgia, which is a common complication after herpes zoster. The other options are not associated with these symptoms. The answer mentions that vaccination with the shingles vaccine in individuals 60-70 years of age can reduce the incidence of this complication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptom mentioned by the patient, constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash, suggests the complication is post-herpetic neuralgia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash suggests post-herpetic neuralgia, which can occur in 20-30% of patients after having herpes zoster. Vaccination with the shingles vaccine in individuals 60-70 years of age can reduce the incidence of this complication.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms described by the patient suggest post-herpetic neuralgia, which is a common complication of herpes zoster infection. Ramsay-Hunt syndrome involves facial nerves, acute herpetic neuralgia is a rare disorder that occurs during the acute stage of herpes zoster, and secondary bacterial infection refers to a bacterial infection on top of the original viral infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash, which are symptoms of post-herpetic neuralgia. This is a common complication of herpes zoster, and the shingles vaccine can help reduce its incidence. Ramsay-Hunt syndrome usually presents with facial paralysis and ear pain, while acute herpetic neuralgia is a term used to describe pain during the active phase of herpes zoster. Secondary bacterial infection can occur if the lesions become infected.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Post-herpetic neuralgia is a common complication of herpes zoster where patients experience constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash even after the rash has resolved. Ramsay-Hunt syndrome is a viral infection of the facial nerve causing facial paralysis, acute herpetic neuralgia is severe pain during the acute stage of the herpes zoster outbreak, and secondary bacterial infection is a potential complication of any skin lesion.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash, which is indicative of post-herpetic neuralgia. This is a common complication of herpes zoster, and the risk of developing it can be reduced by vaccination with the shingles vaccine in individuals aged 60-70 years. Ramsay-Hunt syndrome is a rare complication of herpes zoster that affects the ear and can cause facial paralysis. Acute herpetic neuralgia refers to the pain experienced during the acute phase of herpes zoster outbreak. Secondary bacterial infection refers to a bacterial infection that occurs as a complication of skin lesions caused by herpes zoster.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash points to post-herpetic neuralgia as the complication. Ramsay-Hunt syndrome is characterized by facial paralysis and ear pain rather than burning and hypersensitivity. Acute herpetic neuralgia is not a recognized complication. Secondary bacterial infection is a possible complication but is not the most commonly seen complication in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is experiencing constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash, which is consistent with post-herpetic neuralgia. Ramsay-Hunt syndrome is a complication of herpes zoster that involves the facial nerve. Acute herpetic neuralgia refers to pain during the active phase of herpes zoster. Secondary bacterial infection would involve the skin becoming infected with bacteria after the herpes zoster rash has resolved.
